sn51.20:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā”.
sn51.20:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the four bases of psychic power are developed and cultivated they’re very fruitful and beneficial.

sn51.20:2.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, cattāro iddhipādā kathaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā?

sn51.20:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti—
sn51.20:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

sn51.20:2.3.pli: iti me chando na ca atilīno bhavissati, na ca atippaggahito bhavissati, na ca ajjhattaṃ saṅkhitto bhavissati, na ca bahiddhā vikkhitto bhavissati.
sn51.20:2.3.eng: They think: ‘My enthusiasm won’t be too lax or too tense. And it’ll be neither constricted internally nor scattered externally.’

sn51.20:2.4.eng: And they meditate perceiving before and behind:

sn51.20:2.5.pli: yathā pure tathā pacchā, yathā pacchā tathā pure;
sn51.20:2.5.eng: as before, so behind; as behind, so before;

sn51.20:2.6.pli: yathā adho tathā uddhaṃ, yathā uddhaṃ tathā adho;
sn51.20:2.6.eng: as below, so above; as above, so below;

sn51.20:2.7.pli: yathā divā tathā rattiṃ yathā rattiṃ tathā divā.
sn51.20:2.7.eng: as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day.

sn51.20:2.8.pli: Iti vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
sn51.20:2.8.eng: And so, with an open and unenveloped heart, they develop a mind that’s full of radiance.

sn51.20:2.9.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy …

sn51.20:2.12.pli: iti me vīmaṃsā na ca atilīnā bhavissati, na ca atippaggahitā bhavissati, na ca ajjhattaṃ saṅkhittā bhavissati, na ca bahiddhā vikkhittā bhavissati.
sn51.20:2.12.eng: They think: ‘My inquiry won’t be too lax or too tense. And it’ll be neither constricted internally nor scattered externally.’

sn51.20:2.13.eng: And they meditate perceiving before and behind:

sn51.20:2.14.pli: yathā pure tathā pacchā, yathā pacchā tathā pure;
sn51.20:2.14.eng: as before, so behind; as behind, so before;

sn51.20:2.15.pli: yathā adho tathā uddhaṃ, yathā uddhaṃ tathā adho;
sn51.20:2.15.eng: as below, so above; as above, so below;

sn51.20:2.16.pli: yathā divā tathā rattiṃ, yathā rattiṃ tathā divā.
sn51.20:2.16.eng: as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day.

sn51.20:2.17.pli: Iti vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
sn51.20:2.17.eng: And so, with an open and unenveloped heart, they develop a mind that’s full of radiance.

sn51.20:3.1.eng: And what is enthusiasm that’s too lax?

sn51.20:3.2.eng: It’s when enthusiasm is coupled with laziness.

sn51.20:4.1.eng: And what is enthusiasm that’s too tense?

sn51.20:4.2.eng: It’s when enthusiasm is coupled with restlessness.

sn51.20:5.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ saṅkhitto chando?
sn51.20:5.1.eng: And what is enthusiasm that’s constricted internally?

sn51.20:5.2.eng: It’s when enthusiasm is coupled with dullness and drowsiness.

sn51.20:5.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ saṅkhitto chando.
sn51.20:5.3.eng: This is called enthusiasm constricted internally.

sn51.20:6.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, bahiddhā vikkhitto chando?
sn51.20:6.1.eng: And what is enthusiasm that’s scattered externally?

sn51.20:6.2.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, chando bahiddhā pañca kāmaguṇe ārabbha anuvikkhitto anuvisaṭo—
sn51.20:6.2.eng: It’s when enthusiasm is frequently scattered and diffused externally on account of the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn51.20:6.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bahiddhā vikkhitto chando.
sn51.20:6.3.eng: This is called enthusiasm scattered externally.

sn51.20:7.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pacchāpuresaññī ca viharati—
sn51.20:7.1.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate perceiving before and behind:

sn51.20:7.2.pli: yathā pure tathā pacchā, yathā pacchā tathā pure?
sn51.20:7.2.eng: as before, so behind; as behind, so before?

sn51.20:7.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pacchāpuresaññā suggahitā hoti sumanasikatā sūpadhāritā suppaṭividdhā paññāya.
sn51.20:7.3.eng: It’s when the perception of before and behind is properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom by a mendicant.

sn51.20:7.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pacchāpuresaññī ca viharati—
sn51.20:7.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates perceiving before and behind:

sn51.20:7.5.pli: yathā pure tathā pacchā, yathā pacchā tathā pure.
sn51.20:7.5.eng: as before, so behind; as behind, so before.

sn51.20:8.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathā adho tathā uddhaṃ, yathā uddhaṃ tathā adho viharati?
sn51.20:8.1.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate as below, so above; as above, so below?

sn51.20:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṃ pūraṃ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
sn51.20:8.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant examines their own body up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.

sn51.20:8.3.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ vakkaṃ hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ papphāsaṃ antaṃ antaguṇaṃ udariyaṃ karīsaṃ pittaṃ semhaṃ pubbo lohitaṃ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.
sn51.20:8.3.eng: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’

sn51.20:8.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathā adho tathā uddhaṃ, yathā uddhaṃ tathā adho viharati.
sn51.20:8.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates as below, so above; as above, so below.

sn51.20:9.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathā divā tathā rattiṃ, yathā rattiṃ tathā divā viharati?
sn51.20:9.1.eng: And how does a mendicant meditate as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day?

sn51.20:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yehi ākārehi yehi liṅgehi yehi nimittehi divā chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti, so tehi ākārehi tehi liṅgehi tehi nimittehi rattiṃ chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti;
sn51.20:9.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort, with the same features, attributes, and signs by day as by night.

sn51.20:9.3.pli: yehi vā pana ākārehi yehi liṅgehi yehi nimittehi rattiṃ chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti, so tehi ākārehi tehi liṅgehi tehi nimittehi divā chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti.
sn51.20:9.3.eng: And they develop it with the same features, attributes, and signs by night as by day.

sn51.20:9.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathā divā tathā rattiṃ, yathā rattiṃ tathā divā viharati.
sn51.20:9.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant meditates as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day.

sn51.20:10.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti?
sn51.20:10.1.eng: And how, with an open and unenveloped heart, does a mendicant develop a mind that’s full of radiance?

sn51.20:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ālokasaññā suggahitā hoti divāsaññā svādhiṭṭhitā.
sn51.20:10.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has properly grasped the perception of light, and has properly grasped the perception of day.

sn51.20:10.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
sn51.20:10.3.eng: That’s how, with an open and unenveloped heart, a mendicant develops a mind that’s full of radiance.

sn51.20:11.1.eng: And what is energy that’s too lax? …

sn51.20:13.3.pli: idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ saṅkhittaṃ vīriyaṃ.

sn51.20:14.2.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, vīriyaṃ bahiddhā pañca kāmaguṇe ārabbha anuvikkhittaṃ anuvisaṭaṃ—idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bahiddhā vikkhittaṃ vīriyaṃ …pe….

sn51.20:15.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti?

sn51.20:15.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ālokasaññā suggahitā hoti divāsaññā svādhiṭṭhitā.

sn51.20:15.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.

sn51.20:16.1.eng: And what is mental development that’s too lax? …

sn51.20:18.3.pli: idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ saṅkhittaṃ cittaṃ.

sn51.20:19.2.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, cittaṃ bahiddhā pañca kāmaguṇe ārabbha anuvikkhittaṃ anuvisaṭaṃ—

sn51.20:19.3.pli: idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bahiddhā vikkhittaṃ cittaṃ …pe…

sn51.20:19.4.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.

sn51.20:20.1.eng: And what is inquiry that’s too lax?

sn51.20:20.2.eng: It’s when inquiry is coupled with laziness.

sn51.20:21.1.eng: And what is inquiry that’s too tense?

sn51.20:21.2.eng: It’s when inquiry is coupled with restlessness.

sn51.20:22.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ saṅkhittā vīmaṃsā?
sn51.20:22.1.eng: And what is inquiry that’s constricted internally?

sn51.20:22.2.eng: It’s when inquiry is coupled with dullness and drowsiness.

sn51.20:22.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ajjhattaṃ saṅkhittā vīmaṃsā.
sn51.20:22.3.eng: This is called inquiry constricted internally.

sn51.20:23.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, bahiddhā vikkhittā vīmaṃsā?
sn51.20:23.1.eng: And what is inquiry that’s scattered externally?

sn51.20:23.2.pli: Yā, bhikkhave, vīmaṃsā bahiddhā pañca kāmaguṇe ārabbha anuvikkhittā anuvisaṭā—
sn51.20:23.2.eng: It’s when inquiry is frequently scattered and diffused externally on account of the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn51.20:23.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bahiddhā vikkhittā vīmaṃsā …pe…
sn51.20:23.3.eng: This is called inquiry scattered externally. …

sn51.20:23.4.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
sn51.20:23.4.eng: That’s how, with an open and unenveloped heart, a mendicant develops a mind that’s full of radiance.

sn51.20:23.5.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, bhikkhave, cattāro iddhipādā evaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā.
sn51.20:23.5.eng: When the four bases of psychic power have been developed and cultivated in this way they’re very fruitful and beneficial.

sn51.20:24.1.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitesu kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu catūsu iddhipādesu evaṃ bahulīkatesu, anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti.
sn51.20:24.1.eng: When the four bases of psychic power have been developed and cultivated in this way, a mendicant wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.

sn51.20:24.2.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitesu kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu catūsu iddhipādesu evaṃ bahulīkatesu, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
sn51.20:24.2.eng: When the four bases of psychic power have been developed and cultivated in this way, they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

sn51.21:1.2.pli: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
sn51.21:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:

sn51.21:1.3.pli: ‘ko nu kho maggo, kā paṭipadā iddhipādabhāvanāyā’ti?
sn51.21:1.3.eng: ‘What’s the path and practice for developing the bases of psychic power?’

sn51.21:1.5.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

sn51.21:1.6.pli: iti me chando na ca atilīno bhavissati, na ca atippaggahito bhavissati, na ca ajjhattaṃ saṅkhitto bhavissati, na ca bahiddhā vikkhitto bhavissati.
sn51.21:1.6.eng: They think: “My enthusiasm won’t be too lax or too tense. And it’ll be neither constricted internally nor scattered externally.”

sn51.21:1.7.eng: And they meditate perceiving before and behind:

sn51.21:1.8.pli: yathā pure tathā pacchā, yathā pacchā tathā pure;
sn51.21:1.8.eng: as before, so behind; as behind, so before;

sn51.21:1.9.pli: yathā adho tathā uddhaṃ, yathā uddhaṃ tathā adho;
sn51.21:1.9.eng: as below, so above; as above, so below;

sn51.21:1.10.pli: yathā divā tathā rattiṃ, yathā rattiṃ tathā divā.
sn51.21:1.10.eng: as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day.

sn51.21:1.11.pli: Iti vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
sn51.21:1.11.eng: And so, with an open and unenveloped heart, they develop a mind that’s full of radiance.

sn51.21:1.12.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy …

sn51.21:1.15.pli: iti me vīmaṃsā na ca atilīnā bhavissati, na ca atippaggahitā bhavissati, na ca ajjhattaṃ saṅkhittā bhavissati, na ca bahiddhā vikkhittā bhavissati.
sn51.21:1.15.eng: They think: “My inquiry won’t be too lax or too tense. And it’ll be neither constricted internally nor scattered externally.”

sn51.21:1.16.eng: And they meditate perceiving before and behind:

sn51.21:1.17.pli: yathā pure tathā pacchā, yathā pacchā tathā pure;
sn51.21:1.17.eng: as before, so behind; as behind, so before;

sn51.21:1.18.pli: yathā adho tathā uddhaṃ, yathā uddhaṃ tathā adho;
sn51.21:1.18.eng: as below, so above; as above, so below;

sn51.21:1.19.pli: yathā divā tathā rattiṃ yathā rattiṃ tathā divā’—
sn51.21:1.19.eng: as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day.

sn51.21:1.20.pli: iti vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
sn51.21:1.20.eng: And so, with an open and unenveloped heart, they develop a mind that’s full of radiance.’

sn51.21:2.1.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitesu kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu catūsu iddhipādesu evaṃ bahulīkatesu anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti.
sn51.21:2.1.eng: When the four bases of psychic power have been developed and cultivated in this way, a mendicant wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.

sn51.21:2.2.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitesu kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu catūsu iddhipādesu evaṃ bahulīkatesu, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
sn51.21:2.2.eng: When the four bases of psychic power have been developed and cultivated in this way, they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

sn51.21:2.4.eng: (The six direct knowledges should be told in full.)

sn51.22:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn51.22:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn51.22:1.3.pli: “abhijānāti nu kho, bhante, bhagavā iddhiyā manomayena kāyena brahmalokaṃ upasaṅkamitā”ti?
sn51.22:1.3.eng: “Sir, do you have personal experience of going to the realm of divinity by psychic power with a mind-made body?”

sn51.22:1.4.pli: “Abhijānāmi khvāhaṃ, ānanda, iddhiyā manomayena kāyena brahmalokaṃ upasaṅkamitā”ti.

sn51.22:1.5.pli: “Abhijānāti pana, bhante, bhagavā iminā cātumahābhūtikena kāyena iddhiyā brahmalokaṃ upasaṅkamitā”ti?
sn51.22:1.5.eng: “But do you have personal experience of going to the realm of divinity by psychic power with this body made up of the four principal states?”

sn51.22:1.6.pli: “Abhijānāmi khvāhaṃ, ānanda, iminā cātumahābhūtikena kāyena iddhiyā brahmalokaṃ upasaṅkamitā”ti.

sn51.22:2.1.pli: “Yañca kho omāti, bhante, bhagavā iddhiyā manomayena kāyena brahmalokaṃ upasaṅkamituṃ, yañca kho abhijānāti, bhante, bhagavā iminā cātumahābhūtikena kāyena iddhiyā brahmalokaṃ upasaṅkamitā, tayidaṃ, bhante, bhagavato acchariyañceva abbhutañcā”ti.
sn51.22:2.1.eng: “It’s incredible and amazing that the Buddha is capable of going to the realm of divinity by psychic power with a mind-made body! And that he has personal experience of going to the realm of divinity by psychic power with this body made up of the four principal states!”

sn51.22:2.2.pli: “Acchariyā ceva, ānanda, tathāgatā acchariyadhammasamannāgatā ca, abbhutā ceva, ānanda, tathāgatā abbhutadhammasamannāgatā ca.
sn51.22:2.2.eng: “Ānanda, the Realized Ones are incredible and have incredible qualities. They’re amazing and have amazing qualities.

sn51.22:3.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgato kāyampi citte samodahati cittampi kāye samodahati, sukhasaññañca lahusaññañca kāye okkamitvā viharati;
sn51.22:3.1.eng: Sometimes the Realized One submerges his body in his mind and his mind in his body. He meditates after sinking into a perception of bliss and lightness in the body.

sn51.22:3.2.pli: tasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgatassa kāyo lahutaro ceva hoti mudutaro ca kammaniyataro ca pabhassarataro ca.
sn51.22:3.2.eng: At that time his body becomes lighter, softer, more workable, and more radiant.

sn51.22:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, ayoguḷo divasaṃ santatto lahutaro ceva hoti mudutaro ca kammaniyataro ca pabhassarataro ca;
sn51.22:4.1.eng: Suppose there was an iron ball that had been heated all day. It’d become lighter, softer, more workable, and more radiant.

sn51.22:4.2.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, yasmiṃ samaye tathāgato kāyampi citte samodahati, cittampi kāye samodahati, sukhasaññañca lahusaññañca kāye okkamitvā viharati;
sn51.22:4.2.eng: In the same way, sometimes the Realized One submerges his body in his mind and his mind in his body. He meditates after sinking into a perception of bliss and lightness in the body.

sn51.22:4.3.pli: tasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgatassa kāyo lahutaro ceva hoti mudutaro ca kammaniyataro ca pabhassarataro ca.
sn51.22:4.3.eng: At that time his body becomes lighter, softer, more workable, and more radiant.

sn51.22:5.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgato kāyampi citte samodahati, cittampi kāye samodahati, sukhasaññañca lahusaññañca kāye okkamitvā viharati;
sn51.22:5.1.eng: Sometimes the Realized One submerges his body in his mind and his mind in his body. He meditates after sinking into a perception of bliss and lightness in the body.

sn51.22:5.2.pli: tasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgatassa kāyo appakasireneva pathaviyā vehāsaṃ abbhuggacchati,
sn51.22:5.2.eng: At that time his body easily rises up from the ground into the air.

sn51.22:5.3.pli: so anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti.
sn51.22:5.3.eng: He wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying himself and becoming one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.

sn51.22:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, tūlapicu vā kappāsapicu vā lahuko vātūpādāno appakasireneva pathaviyā vehāsaṃ abbhuggacchati;
sn51.22:6.1.eng: Suppose there was a light tuft of cotton-wool or kapok. Taken up by the wind, it would easily rise up from the ground into the air.

sn51.22:6.2.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, yasmiṃ samaye tathāgato kāyampi citte samodahati, cittampi kāye samodahati, sukhasaññañca lahusaññañca kāye okkamitvā viharati;
sn51.22:6.2.eng: In the same way, sometimes the Realized One submerges his body in his mind and his mind in his body. He meditates after sinking into a perception of bliss and lightness in the body.

sn51.22:6.3.pli: tasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgatassa kāyo appakasireneva pathaviyā vehāsaṃ abbhuggacchati,
sn51.22:6.3.eng: At that time his body easily rises up from the ground into the air.

sn51.22:6.4.pli: so anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vattetī”ti.
sn51.22:6.4.eng: He wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying himself and becoming one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.”

sn51.23:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four bases of psychic power.

sn51.23:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti,
sn51.23:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm …

sn51.23:1.7.eng: These are the four bases of psychic power.

sn51.23:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ iddhipādānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
sn51.23:1.8.eng: By developing and cultivating these four bases of psychic power, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

sn51.24:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four bases of psychic power.

sn51.24:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti,
sn51.24:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm …

sn51.24:1.7.eng: These are the four bases of psychic power.”

sn51.25:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four bases of psychic power.

sn51.25:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti,
sn51.25:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm …

sn51.25:1.7.eng: These are the four bases of psychic power.

sn51.25:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ iddhipādānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā bhikkhunā dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
sn51.25:1.8.eng: Because of developing and cultivating these four bases of psychic power, one of two results can be expected:

sn51.25:1.9.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
sn51.25:1.9.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

sn51.26:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four bases of psychic power.

sn51.26:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti,
sn51.26:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm …

sn51.26:1.7.eng: These are the four bases of psychic power.

sn51.26:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ iddhipādānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā satta phalā sattānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
sn51.26:1.8.eng: Because of developing and cultivating these four bases of psychic power, seven fruits and benefits can be expected.

sn51.26:2.2.eng: They attain enlightenment early on in this very life.

sn51.26:2.3.pli: no ce diṭṭheva dhamme paṭikacca aññaṃ ārādheti; atha maraṇakāle aññaṃ ārādheti,
sn51.26:2.3.eng: If not, they attain enlightenment at the time of death.

sn51.26:2.4.pli: no ce diṭṭheva dhamme paṭikacca aññaṃ ārādheti, no ce maraṇakāle aññaṃ ārādheti; atha pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā antarāparinibbāyī hoti, upahaccaparinibbāyī hoti, asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti, sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti, uddhaṃsoto hoti akaniṭṭhagāmī.
sn51.26:2.4.eng: If not, with the ending of the five lower fetters, they’re extinguished between one life and the next … they’re extinguished upon landing … they’re extinguished without extra effort … they’re extinguished with extra effort … they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

sn51.26:2.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ iddhipādānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā ime satta phalā sattānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
sn51.26:2.5.eng: Because of developing and cultivating these four bases of psychic power, these seven fruits and benefits can be expected.”

sn51.27:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn51.27:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn51.27:2.1.pli: “Katamā nu kho, bhante, iddhi, katamo iddhipādo, katamā iddhipādabhāvanā, katamā iddhipādabhāvanāgāminī paṭipadā”ti?
sn51.27:2.1.eng: “Sir, what is psychic power? What is the basis of psychic power? What is the development of the bases of psychic power? And what is the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power?”

sn51.27:2.2.pli: “Idhānanda, bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti—
sn51.27:2.2.eng: “Ānanda, take a mendicant who wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.

sn51.27:3.1.eng: And what is the basis of psychic power?

sn51.27:3.2.pli: Yo, ānanda, maggo yā paṭipadā iddhilābhāya iddhipaṭilābhāya saṃvattati—
sn51.27:3.2.eng: The path and practice that leads to gaining psychic power.

sn51.27:3.3.eng: This is called the basis of psychic power.

sn51.27:4.1.eng: And what is the development of the bases of psychic power?

sn51.27:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm …

sn51.27:4.6.eng: This is called the development of the bases of psychic power.

sn51.27:5.1.eng: And what is the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power?

sn51.27:5.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn51.27:5.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn51.27:5.4.eng: This is called the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power.”

sn51.28:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn51.28:1.1.eng: The Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda:

sn51.28:1.2.pli: “katamā nu kho, ānanda, iddhi, katamo iddhipādo, katamā iddhipādabhāvanā, katamā iddhipādabhāvanāgāminī paṭipadā”ti?
sn51.28:1.2.eng: “Ānanda, what is psychic power? What is the basis of psychic power? What is the development of the bases of psychic power? And what is the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power?”

sn51.28:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. …”

sn51.28:2.1.pli: “Idhānanda, bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti—
sn51.28:2.1.eng: “Ānanda, take a mendicant who wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.

sn51.28:3.1.eng: And what is the basis of psychic power?

sn51.28:3.2.pli: Yo, ānanda, maggo yā paṭipadā iddhilābhāya iddhipaṭilābhāya saṃvattati—
sn51.28:3.2.eng: The path and practice that leads to gaining psychic power.

sn51.28:3.3.eng: This is called the basis of psychic power.

sn51.28:4.1.eng: And what is the development of the bases of psychic power?

sn51.28:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm …

sn51.28:4.6.eng: This is called the development of the bases of psychic power.

sn51.28:5.1.eng: And what is the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power?

sn51.28:5.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn51.28:5.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn51.28:5.4.eng: This is called the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power.”

sn51.29:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn51.29:1.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn51.29:1.2.pli: “katamā nu kho, bhante, iddhi, katamo iddhipādo, katamā iddhipādabhāvanā, katamā iddhipādabhāvanāgāminī paṭipadā”ti?
sn51.29:1.2.eng: “Sir, what is psychic power? What is the basis of psychic power? What is the development of the bases of psychic power? And what is the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power?”

sn51.29:2.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti—
sn51.29:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, take a mendicant who wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.

sn51.29:3.1.eng: And what is the basis of psychic power?

sn51.29:3.2.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, maggo, yā paṭipadā iddhilābhāya iddhipaṭilābhāya saṃvattati—
sn51.29:3.2.eng: The path and practice that leads to gaining psychic power.

sn51.29:3.3.eng: This is called the basis of psychic power.

sn51.29:4.1.eng: And what is the development of the bases of psychic power?

sn51.29:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti,
sn51.29:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm …

sn51.29:4.6.eng: This is called the development of the bases of psychic power.

sn51.29:5.1.eng: And what is the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power?

sn51.29:5.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn51.29:5.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn51.29:5.4.eng: This is called the practice that leads to the development of the bases of psychic power.”
